event: Norse explorers possibly reach the area during voyages to Vinland.
John Cabot, sailing for England, explores the region including nearby Newfoundland.
Portuguese explorer João Álvares Fagundes maps the islands.
French fishermen begin using the islands seasonally for cod fishing.
France formally claims the islands and establishes settlements.
Treaty of Utrecht cedes Saint Pierre and Miquelon to Britain.
Treaty of Paris returns the islands to France after the Seven Years’ War.
British forces seize the islands during the American Revolutionary War.
France permanently regains control after Napoleonic Wars.
Islands receive new administrative status as a French territorial collectivity.
Free French forces under Charles de Gaulle seize the islands from Vichy control during WWII.
Saint Pierre and Miquelon designated as a French overseas department (later reclassified).
Fishing disputes with Canada lead to ongoing negotiations over maritime boundaries.
International court rules largely in favor of Canada in a maritime boundary dispute.
Status updated to 'overseas collectivity' under the French constitution.
COVID-19 pandemic affects travel and fishing-dependent economy.
